paragraphs.name: f37f
paragraphs.text: Maybe that’s why so many designers are offended when non-designers do design work or get called “designers” by Jared and me. You can act offended if you want, but the reality is that other people are making design decisions with or without you. Embrace them . They don’t make your job less valuable. They don’t make your job title less meaningful.

Whether you like it or not, whether you approve it or not, people outside of your design team are making significant design choices that affect your customers in important ways. They are designing your product. They are designers.
paragraphs.name: 33c1

paragraphs.text: Focusing on the core business is what differentiates real product design from interface design or even user experience design. Fundamental product design is really hard and requires a lot of legwork, but this is what designers at the highest level do — and it’s why their work is better than yours.
paragraphs.name: f2f3
f912
paragraphs.text: Everyone is a designer. Get over it.

This shouldn’t be provocative — it’s just a statement of fact. I work with dozens of startups every year, and I see it happen at every one. A CFO makes a pricing decision and changes the product experience. An engineer makes a performance trade-off. A salesperson calls on a customer. In my view, people who fundamentally change the customer’s experience are designers.
paragraphs.name: ed87

paragraphs.text: Does everyone need all the skills of a designer? Of course not. But each person needs to be armed with the tools to understand how their decisions affect the customer experience.

d276b65c7219.title: Sure. We’re getting a bit pedantic here, but when a CFO chooses a new way to price a product, she…

paragraphs.text: Sure. We’re getting a bit pedantic here, but when a CFO chooses a new way to price a product, she has an intent (i.e. to sell more products at a better margin.) She’s hoping a customer sees the product offering and chooses to spend money. That’s intent. It may not consider the user experience in a very sophisticated way and the downstream effects…
paragraphs.name: b28b

67122ae2468f.title: This is a great read Daniel, it takes me back to a talk that Denise Jacobs gave “Everyone is…

paragraphs.text: This is a great read Daniel, it takes me back to a talk that Denise Jacobs gave “Everyone is Creative”. I think that as designers we have fought so hard to be included in business decisions that we now try to exclude “non-designer roles” from our creative process.

paragraphs.text: I find it incredible that there are designers who feel threatened by this concept. Having more people within an organization thinking about design not only makes the product better, but it makes a designer’s job easier so they can do greater work.

86fac284b614.title: When I saw the title of this article, I thought “Oh please, give me a break!”

paragraphs.text: When I saw the title of this article, I thought “Oh please, give me a break!” But then I read it and it made more sense. When you say that CEOs, engineers, marketing, etc, take part in the design process, I can only agree. However, the title “Everyone is a designer” just reminded me of all those people in my company who know very little about…
paragraphs.name: c9c1

8ea1927605a7.title: I would agree that everyone can affect the product experience but I always think of designing as an…

paragraphs.text: I would agree that everyone can affect the product experience but I always think of designing as an intentional act. So I wouldn’t say they’re designing the product until they have an intent behind their actions.
paragraphs.name: c44e

ac9cc1fe228e.title: I would agree, but only if they are doing so intentionally, with the customer experience in mind.

paragraphs.text: I would agree, but only if they are doing so intentionally, with the customer experience in mind. An engineer who makes a decision based on internal processes that just happens to affect the customer experience is not designing anything.
paragraphs.name: a4ef

ccc04c2e6668.title: This is the TL;DR of the TWO articles written about this idea.

paragraphs.text: This is the TL;DR of the TWO articles written about this idea. Apply this idea to where you fit into an organization — it isn’t a unique trait to Designers. It doesn’t make you a designer, but it will make you really successful at what you do. A user-centered Marketer, a user-center Engineer, a user-center Product Manager, etc.
paragraphs.name: a1ef

3e0be5281623.title: There are many ways to respond to this, but I’ll say this: to be a designer requires empathy, and…

paragraphs.text: There are many ways to respond to this, but I’ll say this: to be a designer requires empathy, and many in the business and tech space lack it. Throwing a wide net, and bringing everyone in the company into the design process is something a good designer should do, but that doesn’t make everyone a designer. I think Jared is just illustrating the fact…
paragraphs.name: cede

1f0e9912baf6.title: Thanks for the insightful perspective Daniel!

paragraphs.text: Thanks for the insightful perspective Daniel! I suspect that some of the negative reaction could be based in a lack of confidence in the value those designers bring to the table. Those of us that identify with the title of designer should be focused on creating outstanding, relevant solutions. I always like to consider the role of designers in the…

beaa3ca4c0f7.title: Having an influence or impact on the experience is not the same as being a designer of that…

paragraphs.text: Having an influence or impact on the experience is not the same as being a designer of that experience. There are lots of grey areas on how a design can be influenced. Your dev team may both influence AND design elements of the work but they may not design the overall experience.
paragraphs.name: eff8
